docs.abstract: People in Beijing show few signs of tension or public concern regarding Deng's death; most people go about their business, with no public display of emotion for one of century's most important leaders; China that Deng left behind has leaders who do not trust the people and people who care little about their leaders because they are far too busy making money; depth of change in China's urban society in recent years--from rising living standards and more access to information--means that many city dwellers do not concern themselves with political leaders as they once did (M)
docs.snippet: Far to one side of Tiananmen Square, under the lazy plane trees that loom over a wide sidewalk, a young man approached the square with a floral wreath in memory of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, who died on Wednesday night.    But he was qu
docs.lead_paragraph: Far to one side of Tiananmen Square, under the lazy plane trees that loom over a wide sidewalk, a young man approached the square with a floral wreath in memory of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, who died on Wednesday night. But he was quickly stopped by a police officer, a stout man in an olive-green uniform who fingered his shiny belt buckle and tilted his head toward a telephone. ''They haven't told me yet whether we agree or not'' to allow the wreath into the square, the policeman said. He was deferring to higher authorities, presumably jittery because they remembered the last time a senior leader died in 1989 and wreath-laying quickly gave way to demonstrating.

docs.abstract: Explosion rocks bus during rush-hour on crowded street in downtown Beijing, alerting police to possibility that recent bombings and unrest among Muslims in Western China had spread to capital; Beijing Daily reports that blast causes more than 10 injuries, and that cause is under investigation; blast appears to be placed and timed for maximum impact; it comes just two weeks after death of Deng Xiaoping and halfway through two-week-long convening of China's legislature, National People's Congress, when delegates from all over country gather in Beijing; explosion appears similar to three simultaneous bombings of buses on Feb 25 in Xinjiang, Muslim region in Western China, which has been plagued by growing violence in recent months (M)

headline.main: 10 People Hurt In an Explosion On Beijing Bus

docs.snippet: An explosion rocked a bus during rush-hour Friday evening on a crowded downtown street, alerting the police to the possibility that recent bombings and unrest among Muslims in Western China had spread to the nation's capital    Reuters reported that
docs.lead_paragraph: An explosion rocked a bus during rush-hour Friday evening on a crowded downtown street, alerting the police to the possibility that recent bombings and unrest among Muslims in Western China had spread to the nation's capital Reuters reported that two people were killed, but that could not be independently confirmed. The Beijing Daily reported early today that the explosion had caused more than 10 injuries but no deaths, adding that Beijing leaders had visited the scene and that the cause was under investigation.

docs.abstract: Crowds of shoppers are as thick as ever on Beijing street where bomb ripped through public bus, seriously injuring at least 10 people; shoppers express surprise that terrorism seems to have arrived in city and reluctance to accept new sense of danger (M)

headline.main: Bus Bombing Fails to Daunt Shopping Day In Beijing

docs.snippet: On North Xidan Street, the crowds of shoppers were as thick as ever today, and the talk of the afternoon was the bomb that ripped through a public bus here on Friday evening.    The police said the explosion was caused by a home-made bomb, and was no
docs.lead_paragraph: On North Xidan Street, the crowds of shoppers were as thick as ever today, and the talk of the afternoon was the bomb that ripped through a public bus here on Friday evening. The police said the explosion was caused by a home-made bomb, and was not accidental, State television said today. At least 10 people were reported seriously injured in the blast.

docs.abstract: Photo of a young person in Beijing using a telescope to observe a total eclipse of the sun

headline.main: The Day Turns to Night Across Parts of Asia

docs.snippet: Photo of a young person in Beijing using a telescope to observe a total eclipse of the sun

docs.abstract: Philippine Government seeks ways to let ranking North Korean defector leave China for Manila en route to his final destination, South Korea; Hwang Jang Yop, most senior North Korean to defect, has been in South Korean consulate in Beijing since Feb 12 (S)

headline.main: Manila in Talks on Fate Of a Korean Defector

docs.snippet: The Philippines said today that it is engaged in talks to let a ranking North Korean defector leave China for Manila, en route to South Korea.    ''There are talks going on, based on the request of the Republic of Korea and also China, to find a way
docs.lead_paragraph: The Philippines said today that it is engaged in talks to let a ranking North Korean defector leave China for Manila, en route to South Korea. ''There are talks going on, based on the request of the Republic of Korea and also China, to find a way of having this gentleman go to his final destination without going through a straight route,'' Domingo Siazon, the Philippine Foreign Minister, said just before leaving on an official trip to Japan.

docs.abstract: Over 55,000 people in Hong Kong defy China and its appointed ruler for territory, Tung Chee-hua, holding vigil to mark 1989 massacre of unarmed protesters near Tiananmen Square, Beijing (M);

headline.main: Demonstrators In Hong Kong Defy Beijing

docs.snippet: A sea of people bathed in points of candlelight gathered this evening in defiance of China and its appointed ruler for the territory to commemorate the massacre of hundreds of unarmed protesters in and around Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 4, 19
docs.lead_paragraph: A sea of people bathed in points of candlelight gathered this evening in defiance of China and its appointed ruler for the territory to commemorate the massacre of hundreds of unarmed protesters in and around Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 4, 1989. Alternately singing and silent, more than 55,000 people -- teachers and preachers, engineers, students, social workers, taxi drivers and bankers -- assembled in Victoria Park in what may be Hong Kong's last memorial to the victims of the Chinese Army's crackdown on the democracy movement eight years ago today.

docs.abstract: Photo of vigil, Hong Kong, marking 1989 killing of unarmed protesters by Chinese Army around Tiananmen Square

headline.kicker: Remembering the Victims of Tiananmen Square
headline.main: Remembering the Victims of Tiananmen Square

docs.snippet: Photo of vigil, Hong Kong, marking 1989 killing of unarmed protesters by Chinese Army around Tiananmen Square

docs.abstract: Beijing Opera is becoming museum piece as fast-modernizing China rapidly leaves behind much of its traditional culture; full-scale productions are rare and foreign tourists make up much of audience; Huguang theater, Beijing, offers weekly morning performance for elderly devotees, mostly forum for amateurs; photo (M)

headline.main: Chinese Old-Timers Keep the Opera Alive, Barely

docs.snippet: Looking a little formal for the occasion in his gray suit and glasses, Liu Feng, a medical doctor, clasped his hands in front of him, bent slightly toward the microphone in the Huguang opera house, and let out a high-pitched squeal.    The audience b
docs.lead_paragraph: Looking a little formal for the occasion in his gray suit and glasses, Liu Feng, a medical doctor, clasped his hands in front of him, bent slightly toward the microphone in the Huguang opera house, and let out a high-pitched squeal. The audience burst into applause, shouting: ''Great! Great!''

docs.abstract: Exuberance is reined in by Chinese authorities in Beijing, where select crowd of approximately 70,000 workers, students, police families and Communist Party members are bused to Tiananmen Square for celebration marking return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule; square is closed to general public for elaborate fireworks display and scripted entertainment extravaganza; photo (M)

headline.main: At Tiananmen Square, Exuberance Is Reined In

docs.snippet: A select crowd of about 70,000 Chinese workers, students, police families and Communist Party members was bused to Tiananmen Square on Monday night for the countdown to the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, which was marked by elaborate fireworks
docs.lead_paragraph: A select crowd of about 70,000 Chinese workers, students, police families and Communist Party members was bused to Tiananmen Square on Monday night for the countdown to the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, which was marked by elaborate fireworks displays and a scripted entertainment extravaganza. When the moment marking the end of China's colonial humiliation by Britain came at midnight on the huge electronic clock here, Beijing was not a city of spontaneous celebration.

docs.abstract: Chrysler Corp plans to close its Beijing, China, office, saying China's sluggish automobile market offers few opportunities for new projects (S)

headline.main: CHRYSLER SAYS IT WILL CLOSE OFFICE IN BEIJING

docs.snippet: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close its Beijing office, saying China's sluggish automobile market offers few opportunities for new projects. The move underscores global companies' disappointment at the slow development of China's auto industry. P
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close its Beijing office, saying China's sluggish automobile market offers few opportunities for new projects. The move underscores global companies' disappointment at the slow development of China's auto industry. Production of cars, trucks and buses grew 2.6 percent last year, barely a quarter of the pace for the whole economy. Larry Burger, director of Chrysler projects in China, said the company no longer saw the need for a representative office. Some sales and marketing staff will be moved to a joint-venture plant making Jeeps in Beijing. Chrysler's bid to expand its China presence was foiled two years ago when Beijing picked Daimler-Benz A.G. to build a $1 billion mini-van and engine factory.
